data.title: paths in jsconfig.json not working in insider
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-insider f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a js project with jsconfig.json:

```json
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "jsx": "react",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
        // This must be specified if "paths" is set
        "baseUrl": "./",
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        // Relative to "baseUrl"
        "paths": {
            "common/*": ["src/common/*"]
        }
    }
}

```

then press F3 to go to definition, then failed with cannot find any definition for xxx.

Same project will work in vscode-stable.

2.

data.title: Autoupdate doesn't seem to detect build architecture (32/64 bits) and grabs the wrong one
data.body:
It would appear that the autoupdate feature in Code is not checking if the build is 32 or 64 bits, favouring the 32bit version. I said yes to an autoupdate prompt and I had the 64bit build installled, yet it went and fetched the 32bit build which told me:
_"Please uninstall the 64-bit version of Code before installing this 32-bit version."_

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Fresh install the 64bit standard build of Code.
2. When launched, it says it needs to update with the little titlebar prompt, you say "Update now" and then you'll see:

> Setup
> Please uninstall the 64-bit version of Code before installing this 32-bit version.

data.title: VSCode C/C++ Extension(ms-vscode.cpptools) can be cached?
data.body:
As my usage, I usually open 2 or more Linux Kernel Source projects in vscode, it's very huge.
When I open vscode, ms-vscode.cpptools will auto start preparation of C/C++ IntelliSense, such as symbol search ing, goto defination and so on.
But as I say, the project of kernel source code is very huge and ms-vscode.cpptools will take a lot of time to finish. Every time I open vscode, this preparation job will run again and take a lot of time.
I'm thinking that ms-vscode.cpptools should add cache support for a project.

data.title: Compound debugging sessions doesn't seem to allow jumping between sessions
data.body:
When using Compound debugging sessions we no longer allow users to seamlessly jump between the two debugging sessions, which limits the experience, as it's not clear that you manually have to switch to the other debugging session to continue debugging.

See this video https://youtu.be/zdKFecmI8Ko

The issue is that when breaking on a Chrome breakpoint after execution is resumed, then a breakpoint on the Node debug session is hit, but this isn't clear in the UI, as you manually have to switch to the Node debug session to see this.

It didn't use to be this way, as we automatically jumped between debugging sessions to create a seamless experience in earlier builds.

- VSCode Version: Version 1.16.1 (1.16.1) + insiders

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone https://github.com/glimpse/stickerapp
2. Checkout chrisdias/ignite2017 branch
3. Start compoun debug session

data.title: Insiders: Stop debugging doesn't stop the node process
data.body:
Mac
Insiders 1.17.0 f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a

scaffold a new express app

``` console
express myexpapp
cd myexpapp && npm install
code-insiders .
```

Generate `launch.json` by clicking on the gear in the debug viewlet, looks like this:

``` json
{
    // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible attributes.
    // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
    // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/www"
        }
    ]
}
```

`F5` to start/debug the app
browse to `localhost:3000`
stop the debugger
`F5` again

result: port 3000 is in use

the node process is still running:

``` console
chris            75258   0.0  0.5  3686816  78276   ??  S     8:43PM   0:01.00 /usr/local/bin/node --debug-brk=45606 --nolazy bin/www
```

So, you can only debug once.

data.title: Module resolution displays incorrectly in a certain case

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.16.1 - OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5 Steps to Reproduce: 1. When using the `import` syntax in JS and TypeScript, VSCode doesn't display the types filename correctly. Given the file hierarchy: The file `main.ts` contains the code: ```typescript import Rect from './shape/Rect'; import Fill from './fill/Fill'; main(); function main(){ let startRect = new Rect(20, 20); let matrix = startRect.render(true); Fill.getPoints(matrix); } ``` The compiled javascript file also displays the error: ```javascript "use strict"; Object.defineProperty(exports, "__esModule", { value: true }); const Rect_1 = require("./shape/Rect"); const Fill_1 = require("./fill/Fill"); main(); function main() { let startRect = new Rect_1.default(20, 20); let matrix = startRect.render(true); Fill.getPoints(matrix); } ``` **Inside of VSCode** the file renders `'./fill/Fill'` as `'./filFill'`. The filepath still resolves correctly and the missing `l/` characters are still deletable (nothing happens on-delete, they act as invisible characters Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Existing file is replaced with empty file when no disk space is available

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
If saving a file fails because there is no disk space left not only the changes are not saved (which would be expected), but the original file is replaced with an empty one, loosing any previous contents which were already on disk.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: OS X (10.11.5)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open existing file
2. Update file
3. (run out of disk space)
4. Try to save file (it will fail)
5. Re open file, it will be empty.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Broken fuzzy search algorithm in picker

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The fuzzy search algorithm can be improved to solve all problems listed in #27317, but IMHO it's completely broken and it should be rewritten from scratch. Let me show you some of the errors I've found:

### Doesn't work with leading spaces

This is the expected behavior:

![ok_todop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1812093/30786853-bf457bbe-a17c-11e7-8ec2-aa033d618db4.gif)

This is what happens if the strings have some leading spaces (useful for extensions like [Projects+](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=fabiospampinato.vscode-projects-plus) for showing a tree-like structure):

![broken_todop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1812093/30786852-bf3df376-a17c-11e7-873e-8ecfc9c97465.gif)

### Not really "fuzzy"

As I understand it, the term "fuzzy" in "fuzzy search" basically means that the characters provided in the search query can have 0 or more other arbitrary characters between them in the matching string. The current algorithm looks like regular search instead:

![broken_fuzzy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1812093/30786850-bf2daa20-a17c-11e7-8b45-0ce237e75cbe.gif)

### Overly strict about string position

For some reasons there are strings that match against some queries, but don't mach against less specific versions of those queries. I mean, a more specific query should provide the same or less results, not more, right?

![broken_start](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1812093/30786851-bf370bba-a17c-11e7-9b5d-3154847c59b4.gif)

data.title: Hurried `Command not found` error because the extensions are not loaded yet
Need a larger gap between the line number and the code text

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-autohotkey|sle|0.2.1

There needs to be a wider gap between the left vertical bar where the line number and other features like collapse/expand is located because 80% of the time I want to place my caret at the beginning of the text by clicking in front of the character I hit the vertical bar instead
1  MyCls = function ()
2  {
3      ...
n  }
_^ there

To place the caret in front, you need to click on the character itself which for many of us with our neural net trained to click in front, or more precisely trained to click in between characters,  causes some issues specifically when doing for the first character

A gap the size of a space should be sufficient to rid of this annoyance
The mouse cursor should be the ibeam when in that gap
The mouse cursor should be the right pointing mouse when it is beyond the gap further to the left.  In fact it should be the right cursor NOW instead of the left one...


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. try to click in front of the first character on the line when the line start as at the edge, unless you are pixel perfect, most the time you will click the left bar instead 


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

Messy template that mixes PHP HTML & AngularJS (v1) breaks syntax highlighting https://gist.github.com/joshribakoff/eec82fdf61209db815b682069110dcec

intelliJ, and sublime both handle this fine. Atom also messes up but in a different way than VSCode. I would not be surprised to hear the code is invalid, but Sublime does handle it fine anyways.

data.title: Theming for descendant scopes not working per TextMate documentation
data.body:
When attempting to use descendant scopes in a VS Code theme, the scopes aren't picked up.

- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Mac OS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Edit a theme with no other `tokenColors` by adding:
```
"tokenColors": [
        {
            "name": "[VSCODE-CUSTOM] Import",
            "scope": "source.ts meta.import-equals.external.ts",
            "settings": {
                "foreground": "#D983F5"
            }
        }
    ]
```
2. run "Reload Window" & make sure you're using the current theme you're editing.

When using `"scope": "meta.import-equals.external.ts"`, the setting is applied:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1024544/30785073-54463568-a115-11e7-96f4-4ebab4f2e049.png)

When using `"scope": "source.ts meta.import-equals.external.ts" no settings are applied:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1024544/30785079-6c78bcb4-a115-11e7-8ea9-9c2a7a3f4e41.png)

I've tested this with a number of existing themes that have the TextMate descendant scopes and have found that none of them are being applied. It's not clear from the Code Theme creation documentation that it shouldn't work.

Reproduces without extensions: N/A (can't use themes with extensions disabled as far as I can tell)

Also to confirm with an existing example from the docs, I attempted to replicate `meta.selector.css entity.name.tag` from https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/themes-snippets-colorizers:

```
 {
            "name": "Functions",
            "scope": [
                "entity.name.function",
                "meta.selector.css entity.name.tag",
                "entity.name.method - source.java"
            ],
            "settings": {
                "foreground": "#ff0000"
            }
        }
```
The descendant scope was not applied:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1024544/30792198-5195b214-a16d-11e7-8984-81576f342560.png)

The `entity.name.function` was applied:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1024544/30792209-689d85b8-a16d-11e7-882c-24b34cd36a2a.png)

**Resources**

[TextMate Scope Documentation](https://manual.macromates.com/en/scope_selectors)

data.title: Terminal window content, wordwrapped content is not suitable for "problemsMatcher" integration
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:09.760Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
ng-template|Ang|0.1.7
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.2
githistory|don|0.2.3
gitlens|eam|5.2.0
tslint|eg2|1.0.9
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.1
Angular2|joh|2.7.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.3.0

---
I have a problem with the multiline problemsMatcher and word wrapped results in the terminal console. 

When I integrate jasmine error reports to vscode "problems" tab and my vscode window is small, the reported error lines are cut at the visual width of the terminal window. Because multiline pattern matching works line by line, those wrapped lines doesn't contains whole information and  are not consistent any more with my pattern matching regex expressions. 

Is there any way to disable word wrapping in the terminal window or do you have any other workaround maybe ? 

I tested with two different terminals (Git Bash and win. PowerShell), because both have the same behavior I think the wrapping is at the vscode side ?   
  
Steps to Reproduce:

I describe whole integration between jasmine and vscode in [this blog article](http://bisaga.com/blog/programming/testing-typescript-node-app-with-jasmine/) 

1. create project with jasmine tests, run jasmine in the terminal successfully, then 
2. create task with the content: 
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "command": "run",
    "args": [],
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "test",
            "command": "node_modules/.bin/jasmine",
            "type": "shell",
            "isBackground": true,
            "presentation": {
                "echo": true,
                "reveal": "always",
                "focus": false,
                "panel": "dedicated"
            },
            "problemMatcher": {
                "owner": "javascript",
                "fileLocation": ["absolute"],
                "severity": "error",
                "pattern": [
                    {
                        "regexp": "Message.*"
                    },
                    {
                        "regexp": "[^ ](.*)",
                        "message": 1
                    },
                    {
                        "regexp": "Stack.*"
                    },
                    {
                        "regexp": "at +.*\\((.*\\\\*.ts):(\\d+):(\\d+)\\)",
                        "file": 1,
                        "line": 2,
                        "column": 3
                    }
                ]
            }
        }            
            
    ]
}
3. run the task with maximized size of the terminal window , pattern matcher does recognize errors and create problem in the problems tab
An error line (where the last regex pattern looks for file, line and column) looks like: 

`
        at UserContext.it (c:\Bisaga\Workspaces\learning\mytest\spec\myapi-spec.ts:16:32) 
`

4. run the task with very narrow size of the terminal window, pattern matcher does not recognize errors any more because the error line reported from the jasmine is now in 3 lines ...
An error line from jasmine is now in the 3 lines instead of the one : 

```
        at UserContext.it (c:\Bisaga\Worksp
aces\learning\mytest\spec\myapi-spec.ts:16:
32)
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Add support for intersecting decorators

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Let's say I'm applying 2 decorators to the following string: `foo bar foo`, the first one changes the color of the whole string to green, the second makes `bar` red. With the current implementation the whole string will be green.

I think a better system would take into account the order in which decorators are applied. For instance if I apply the `red` decorator after the `green` one, it should take precedence and make `bar` red, while still keeping the rest green.

This kind of logic can already be implemented in an extension, but it seems low-level and general enough to deserve to be implemented in VSC itself.

What do you think?

data.title: connected variables can not be modified properly with snippet function
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
gitignore|cod|0.5.0
arm|dan|0.1.2
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.4
snippet-creator|nik|0.0.4
vim|vsc|0.10.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add the following snippet to c.json

```
"Header Include-Guard": {
    "prefix": "once",
    "body": [
        "#ifndef __${1:NAME}_H__\r",
        "#define __${1:NAME}_H__\r",
        "\r",
        "$0\r",
        "\r",
        "#endif /* __${1:NAME}_H__ */"
    ]
}
```

2. Create an c language file, and insert the snippet, then the cursor would be end of three NAME strings.  Press the Backspace key once, the first __NAME_H__will be changed to __, and the other two strings will be kept unchanged.

by the way, the issue is gone if I disable the vim extension.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
